Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics in the Mesosphere and Lower Thermosphere over the Andes Lidar Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 5-year scientific collaboration to investigate the dynamics in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) over the Andes Mountains in northern Chile. The objective is to characterize and understand wave phenomenology in the 80 to 100 km region, including background state interactions and effects. The investigation will be carried out at the newly established Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) at Cerro Pachón (30.3°S, 70.7°W, 2530 m), Chile. This location is uniquely important for wave studies because it is a region of steep terrain and prolific wave generation that produces particularly pure examples of terrain generated waves due to the extreme dryness of the area and relative lack of convection, and it provides data for a region, the subtropical Southern Hemisphere, that currently is poorly characterized in terms of planetary waves, tides and gravity waves. The suite of instruments at ALO comprises a Na wind/temperature lidar, an all sky imager, a multichannel photometer, a mesospheric temperature mapper, an infrared camera, and a meteor radar, which will be used to observe waves and wave phenomena over a wide range of spatial and temporal scales. The project aims to provide the most detailed study to date from a Southern Hemisphere mountainous site of the characteristics and variability of instabilities, gravity waves, tides, planetary waves and mean winds and their interactions over a continuous 5-year period. Specific questions that will be addressed include:
1) What is the climatology of waves and wave related phenomenology over the Andes?
2) What are the origins, lifecycle and morphology of instabilities at ALO?
3) What atmospheric conditions lead to the formation of various wave phenomena?
4) What are the characteristics of the interactions between tides, planetary waves and gravity waves and their effects on the MLT variability?

The project will provide new education and training opportunities for students at all three universities involved. International collaborations with strong student involvement will also be pursued under this project with the Ciudad Universitaria, Argentina and the University of Adelaide, Australia. The unique dataset collected during this project will be made available to the scientific community and will support research on a wide range of scientific topics in both atmospheric science and astronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to obtain data from the Aerospace Nightglow Imager (ANI), part of the Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) at Cerro Pachon Chile, that can be used to address a number of questions regarding the dynamics of the mesopause region located at about 85 km altitude.  This region is modified by atmospheric gravity waves, which are produced by tropospheric disturbances from below (such as thunderstorms or airflow over mountain ranges) which then propagate up to higher altitudes, as they rise in altitude the waves grow in amplitude and eventually breakdown into turbulent features. The breakdown often occurs in the 80 to 90 km altitude region. Fortuitously, these altitudes produce a natural nighttime emission, the airglow, which the ANI instrument is imaging. Thus, as the waves break down the airglow is modified and the entire process, including the production of turbulence can be imaged. The formation and properties of wave breakdown is difficult to study on the ground and therefore the mesopause region is a natural laboratory for such investigations which can be studied via the airglow imaging technique. In addition to wave breakdown, wave-driven variations of the winds and tides can also cause this part of the atmosphere to go unstable, leading to the formation of instabilities and turbulence which can also be seen via this technique


The location of the imager at Cerro Pachon Chile has two additional advantages. This mountain, home of many of the world’s great astronomical telescopes, has some of the best nighttime seeing in the world, thus allowing for a large number of observations. Secondly, the location in the Andes allows a study of a particular type of gravity wave, mountain waves (MWs), which propagate nearly straight up and stay nearly stationary with respect to the ground thus allowing a large period of observation, a crucial attribute for studying wave breakdown.


With this background there were several main outcomes of this work which were published in the peer-reviewed scientific literature and presented at major scientific meetings, open to the public.


1. Classically, the atmosphere can be characterized by the Richardson (Ri) number which depends on the atmospheric wind shear and temperature gradient. Using auxiliary ALO instruments we can measure Ri in the airglow layer. We did a case study using ANI image data on March 24, 2012. During this period the atmosphere was dynamically unstable (Ri <1/4) and instability features were observed to move with the wind consistent with the formation of classic instabilities. The characteristics of these instabilities were consistent with model predictions. Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS) shows similar fine structure instabilities as seen in the ANI images. After 630 UT the well-organized instability phasefronts decay into what appears to be large scale turbulence with "wavelengths" on the order of a few km.  During this turbulence period the amplitude of the turbulent structures oscillate close to the Brunt-Vaisala period (the natural oscillation period of the atmosphere at this altitude). This may represent an enhanced signal due to the decay of the  instabilities into turbulent eddies affected by buoyancy.


2. While the above study suggested that classical models were accurate in predicting instability formation, ANI data showed many instances (especially older airglow observations over Maui) when the atmosphere was stable classically, yet instability-like features were still observed. We modeled a different mechanism for instability formation, the Parametric Instability Mechanism. We have found that this mechanism generates instabilities when the background atmosphere appears to be stable. This may account for some of the instabilities seen in ANI images, suggesting that this mechanism may be an important process in generating instabilities in the airglow altitude region. 


3. MWs appear to be a ubiquitous feature of the wintertime southern Andes mesoapuse region.  Since MWs have near zero phase speed, and zero wind lines often occur in the winter upper mesosphere (80 to 100 km altitude) region due to the reversal of the zonal mean and tidal wind, MW breakdown may routinely occur at these altitudes. During the night of July 8-9, 2012 MWs were observed at very high-spatial/temporal resolution and these observations revealed for the first time the initiation of MW breakdown in the mesopause region. Because the waves are nearly stationary, the breakdown process was observed over several hours; a much longer interval than has previously been observed for any gravity wave breakdown. During the breakdown process observations were made of initial horseshoe shaped vortices, leading to successive vortex rings, as is also commonly seen in DNS of idealized and multi-scale gravity wave breaking. Kelvin-Helmholtz instability (KHI) structures were also observed to form. Comparing the structure of observed KHI with the results of existing DNS allowed an estimate of the turbulent kinematic viscosity. This viscosity was found to be around 25 m2/s near 83 km, a value larger than the nominal viscosity that is used in models.
